Identifying Microservices

Outline (Identifying Microservices)

  1. Identifying Microservices [4]
  2. How to get there? [3]
  3. Conclusions [2]
Identifying Microservices Erik Wilde (@dret): API Scope Identification

(3) Microservices for the Masses?

  • Microservices are an investment and not a default choice
    • The cost is the need for advanced infrastructure and teams
    • The return is increased flexibility and agility
    • Cost/benefit for microservices is targeted at long term capabilities
  • What are the prerequisites for considering microservices? [http://martinfowler.com/bliki/MicroservicePrerequisites.html]
    1. Rapid Provisioning: Automated process to quickly create server infrastructure
    2. Monitoring: Multi-level monitoring from service health to business-level logic
    3. Rapid Deployment: Automated ways to quickly move from code to running services
  • Moving to MSA is a transition process and not one Big Bang
    • Just like the Web is never complete/final, neither is a microservices landscape


Identifying Microservices Erik Wilde (@dret): API Scope Identification

(4) Containerization!

  • Containerization is the gateway drug for microservices. [http://www.apiacademy.co/resources/api360-microservices-summit-microservices-blind-spots/]
  • Containers exist because of CI/CD (rapid deployment)
  • Containers allow agility on the development and deployment level
  • MSA allows agility on the service ecosystem level
  • MSA without (some form of) containerization is hard to imagine


Identifying Microservices Erik Wilde (@dret): API Scope Identification

(5) How Micro?

  • There is no hard limit on the size of a Microservice
  • Domain limits (DDD) are a good starting point
  • Team size (Conway's Law [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conway's_law]) is a good starting point


Identifying Microservices Erik Wilde (@dret): API Scope Identification

(6) How Micro? The Good News!

  • MSA tells you to keep services independent and agile
  • MSA is a continuous process of reassessing services and their utility
    • If a service is too big, split service and team and relaunch the new services
    • If granularity is too small, join teams and services and relaunch the new service
  • â¦but still not a simple answer to the how big? question


How to get there?

Outline (How to get there?)

  1. Identifying Microservices [4]

  3. Conclusions [2]
How to get there? Erik Wilde (@dret): API Scope Identification

(8) Transformation: Changing vs. Changeable

  • Changing implies a one-time activity
  • Changeable implies an intrinsic property

    Don't focus on what to change into;
    Focus on embracing change as your mode of existence.



How to get there? Erik Wilde (@dret): API Scope Identification

(9) Strangling the Monolith



How to get there? Erik Wilde (@dret): API Scope Identification

(10) How to Strangle Well

  • Manage access to old/new capabilities through a router or gateway
    • Transitioning is a management process old/new should be unaware of
  • Data sync/update is a separately managed process
    • Sophistication and cost of sync/update depends on consistency requirements
    • When one of the services disappears sync/update can be removed
  • Manage/monitor transition of service replacement
    • At some point in time decommissioning may be the most economical option
    • Until then the strangled monolith is the best case scenario

(12) Learning by Doing

  • Identify an MVP and get started
  • Start sharing experiences and establish a culture
